responses.text: I've spent over a decade in senior-level roles across communications, marketing, and project management. Most recently at ScarlettAbbott, I've been helping clients like Pernod Ricard, Coca Cola, and British Gas improve their employee experience through behavior change programs and learning solutions.

follow_ups.text: At ScarlettAbbott, I take a holistic view of employee experience, using client and industry data to diagnose root problems. I've led AI adoption programs, built gamified learning experiences, and designed communication strategies that cut through the noise. My clients range from energy companies to FMCG giants‚Äîeach needing tailored, evidence-based solutions.

Before ScarlettAbbott, I worked at We Are Brass Tacks embedding safety frameworks for Fortune 500 companies using behavioral science. I also spent time at 17 Triggers in Cambodia, running HCD workshops for clients like UNICEF and USAID. That's where I really fell in love with human-centered design as a tool for behavior change.

responses.text: I'm an Employee Experience Specialist with a passion for behavior change. I completed my MBA in 2025 and a NanoMBA in Behavioral Science in 2024. I also wrote a book called 'Fan Centric Design' about applying design thinking to fan engagement‚Äîwhich turned out to be surprisingly relevant to employee engagement too.

follow_ups.text: Behavioral science is at the core of everything I do. I use frameworks like the Elephant-Rider-Path model to design interventions that stick. Whether it's a compliance training program or an internal comms campaign, I'm always thinking about cognitive biases, motivation, and habit formation. My MBA thesis explored dark patterns in employee engagement, which was... eye-opening.

Fan Centric Design applies service design principles to fan experiences. I wrote it after years in the entertainment industry, but the parallels to employee experience are everywhere‚Äîunderstanding needs, creating emotional connections, designing for moments that matter. It's available on Amazon if you're curious!

responses.text: I'm a bit of a generalist, which I know can sound wishy-washy, but hear me out. I've managed marketing teams, built brands from scratch, designed learning experiences, written code, facilitated workshops, and even managed a nightclub empire. That breadth means I can speak fluently across disciplines and build solutions end-to-end.

follow_ups.text: Ha, yes. I ran Neverland‚Äîa nightlife business across Glasgow and Aberdeen with 25-30 staff. I learned branding, HR, finance, event management, and how to communicate with everyone from bartenders to accountants. It was chaotic and brilliant. I eventually sold it to focus on L&D, but those years taught me how to manage complexity and keep teams aligned.

I don't just strategize‚ÄîI execute. I can design a learning program, build the digital assets, write the content, code the experience, and report on the outcomes. That's rare in L&D. Most people specialize, but I've deliberately stayed broad so I can own entire projects from concept to delivery.

intro_questions.text: What made you apply for this role?

responses.text: Nestl√©'s focus on digital transformation in learning really resonates with me. The GROW platform launch is exactly the kind of project I thrive on‚Äîrolling out new tech, supporting adoption, and making sure it actually delivers value. Plus, compliance training is criminally under-designed. I'd love to change that.

follow_ups.text: Learning platforms are only as good as the experience they create. I've worked with LMS implementations before, and the common failure point is adoption‚Äîpeople don't use them because they're clunky or irrelevant. My approach would be to obsess over user experience, create compelling content, and build a communication strategy that makes people actually want to engage.

Compliance training is usually a checkbox exercise. People click through slides, retain nothing, and move on. But it doesn't have to be that way. I've built compliance programs that use storytelling, scenario-based learning, and gamification to make the content stick. It's still compliant, but it's actually effective.

responses.text: I've been following Nestl√©'s commitment to diversity and inclusion, and it aligns with my own values. I've worked across cultures‚ÄîCambodia, France, Scotland‚Äîand I've seen firsthand how diverse perspectives drive better outcomes. I want to work somewhere that takes that seriously.

follow_ups.prompt: Tell me more: Working across cultures
follow_ups.text: When I was at 17 Triggers in Cambodia, I facilitated workshops with UNICEF and GIZ on topics like child labor and gender equity. You can't just import Western frameworks‚Äîyou have to deeply understand local context, power dynamics, and cultural norms. That experience made me a much better designer and communicator.

responses.text: Honestly? I want to work on something that matters. Learning and development has a direct impact on people's growth, confidence, and careers. I've spent years in marketing and comms, which is fun, but L&D feels more meaningful. And Nestl√©'s scale means the impact is huge.

follow_ups.text: I've done a lot of commercial work‚Äîselling products, driving revenue, optimizing funnels. It's fine, but it doesn't light me up the way learning does. When I see someone have an 'aha' moment in a workshop, or when a comms campaign actually changes behavior, that's the good stuff. That's why I'm here.

intro_questions.text: What makes you unique for this role?

responses.text: I'm technical. I can code, design, and build digital experiences from scratch. Most L&D specialists rely on vendors or IT teams, but I can prototype learning tools, analyze data in Python, and even build game-like simulations. That makes me fast and self-sufficient.

follow_ups.text: I've built websites, designed learning games, created data dashboards, and automated reporting workflows. I'm comfortable in Figma, Webflow, the Adobe suite, and I can write JavaScript and Python when needed. That technical fluency means I can move fast and don't need hand-holding.

responses.text: I understand stakeholder management at scale. I've worked with global teams, regional partners, and local stakeholders across multiple industries. I know how to adapt my communication style, build consensus, and deliver on competing priorities without dropping the ball.

follow_ups.text: At ScarlettAbbott, I've managed projects with C-suite sponsors, factory floor workers, and everyone in between. At 17 Triggers, I coordinated with UN agencies, government ministries, and grassroots NGOs. Each group has different needs, incentives, and communication preferences. My job is to navigate that complexity.

responses.text: I'm a systems thinker. I don't just design a training module‚ÄîI think about the entire ecosystem. How does this fit into the employee journey? What barriers exist? What incentives are in play? That holistic view means my solutions are more likely to work in the real world.

follow_ups.text: I use frameworks like the Elephant-Rider-Path model and 70-20-10 to map out interventions. I also think about Kotter's change management principles, Fogg's behavior model, and even dark logic considerations‚Äîwhat unintended consequences might this create? That depth means fewer surprises down the line.

responses.text: I'm scrappy. I've built businesses, managed teams, and delivered projects with limited budgets and tight deadlines. I don't wait for perfect conditions‚ÄîI ship, iterate, and improve. That bias toward action is invaluable in fast-moving environments.

follow_ups.text: When I ran What's On Phnom Penh, we had no budget for designers or developers. So I taught myself. When I needed to scale Neverland, I learned HR and finance. I don't see constraints as blockers‚ÄîI see them as design challenges. That mindset is how I've delivered so much with so little.
